questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices:
Halloween is when lovers exchange cards and
gifts.
Halloween has its roots in an ancient pagan festival marking the beginning of winter.
questions.explanation: Halloween is an ancient festival and has its roots in the pagan festival to mark the beginning of winter.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The Proms is an eight-week summer season of classical orchestral music.
The Proms is a series of tennis matches held every June in London.
questions.explanation: The Proms is an eight-week summer season of orchestral classical music that takes place in various venues, including the Royal Albert Hall in London.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Some people rent land called 'an allotment', where they grow fruit and vegetables.
questions.explanation:
A lot of people have gardens at home and will spend their free
time looking after them. Some people rent additional land called ‘an allotment’, where they grow fruit and vegetables.

questions.question: Who appoints life peers in the House of Lords?
choices: The Speaker of the House of Commons
questions.explanation: Life peers are appointed by the monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister.

questions.question: In which battle during the First World War did the British suffer 60,000 casualties on the first day?
questions.explanation: In July 1916 the British suffered 60,000 casualties on the first day of the Battle of the Somme.

questions.question: Who opens the new parliamentary session each year?
choices: The Speaker of the House of Commons
questions.explanation: The King has important ceremonial roles, such as the opening of the new parliamentary session each year.

questions.question: Which TWO are famous British authors?
questions.explanation: Thomas Hardy's best-known novels include Far from the Madding Crowd and Jude the Obscure. Graham Greene's novels include The Heart of the Matter, The Honorary Consul, Brighton Rock and Our Man in Havana.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Charles, king of Scotland, was crowned King Charles II of England in 1660.
Bonnie Prince Charlie became King Charles II of England in 1660.
questions.explanation:
The Scots declared Charles II to be king. He was crowned king of Scotland and led a Scottish army into England. After defeat at the Battles of Dunbar and Worcester, he fled to Europe. In May 1660, Parliament invited him to come back from exile in
the Netherlands. He was crowned King Charles II of England, Wales,
Scotland and Ireland.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Anybody can be asked to serve on a jury, no matter how old they are.
questions.explanation: Anyone who is on the electoral register and is aged 18–70 (18–75 in England and Wales) can be asked to serve on a jury.

questions.question: Which TWO of these figures were great Scottish thinkers of the Enlightenment?
choices: Robert Louis Stevenson and David Hume
Robert Burns and Robert Louis Stevenson
questions.explanation: Many of the great thinkers of the Enlightenment were Scottish. Adam Smith developed ideas about economics. David Hume wrote about human nature.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
'The Restoration' refers to the re-establishment of Catholicism as the official Church in the 17th century.
questions.explanation:
In May 1660, Parliament invited Charles II to come back from exile in the Netherlands. He was crowned King Charles II of England, Wales,
Scotland and Ireland. This is referred to as 'The Restoration'.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Thomas Hardy was a famous author who wrote Far from the Madding Crowd.
questions.explanation: Thomas Hardy (1840–1928) was an author and poet. His best-known novels focus on rural society and include Far from the Madding Crowd and Jude the Obscure.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The Chancellor of the Exchequer is responsible for crime, policing and immigration.
The Chancellor of the Exchequer is responsible for the economy.
questions.explanation: The Chancellor of the Exchequer is the cabinet minister responsible for the economy.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Britain has never been at war with France.
questions.explanation: Britain fought a number of wars with France during the Middle Ages and later.

questions.question: Which area of government policy is the responsibility of the Chancellor of the Exchequer?
questions.explanation: The Chancellor of the Exchequer is responsible for the economy, and is a member of the cabinet.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Magistrates usually work unpaid and do not need legal qualifications.
Magistrates must be specially trained legal experts who have been solicitors for three years.
questions.explanation: Magistrates are members of the local community. They usually work unpaid and do not need legal qualifications.

questions.question: What was the Beveridge Report of 1942 about?
choices: How to end the war in Europe
How to treat the Germans and Japanese after the war
questions.explanation: The Beveridge Report of 1942, called Social Insurance and Allied Services, recommended that the government should find ways of fighting the five 'Giant Evils' of Want, Disease, Ignorance, Squalor and Idleness and provided the basis of the modern welfare state.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The Speaker of the House of Commons remains a Member of Parliament (MP) after election as Speaker.
The Speaker of the House of Commons has to give up being an MP when elected as Speaker.
questions.explanation: The Speaker is neutral and does not represent a political party, but he or she remains an MP, represents a constituency and deals with constituents’ problems like any other MP.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The Wimbledon Championships are associated with motor sports.
questions.explanation: The Wimbledon Championships is the oldest tennis tournament in the world.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are famous British authors?
choices: Gustav Holst and J K Rowling
Sir Steve Redgrave and Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
Sir Steve Redgrave and Gustav Holst
Sir Arthur Conan Doyle and J K Rowling
questions.explanation: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle was a Scottish doctor and writer. He was best known for his stories about Sherlock Holmes, who was one of the first fictional detectives. J K Rowling wrote the Harry Potter series of children’s books, which have enjoyed huge international success. She now writes fiction for adults as well.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
All young people are sent a National Insurance number just before their 16th birthday.
questions.explanation: All young people in the UK are sent a National Insurance number just before their 16th birthday. It makes sure that the National Insurance Contributions and tax you pay are properly recorded against your name.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: There is no place in British society for extremism or intolerance.
Britain encourages people to have extreme views and to act upon them.
questions.explanation: British society is founded on fundamental values and principles which all those living in the UK should respect and support. There is no place for extremism or intolerance.

questions.question: Which TWO events are Christian festivals?
questions.explanation: Easter and Christmas are two Christian festivals. Christmas celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ, and Easter marks his death on Good Friday and his rising from the dead on Easter Sunday.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: 'The Divine Right of Kings' was the idea that the English king should rule France.
'The Divine Right of Kings' was the idea that the king was directly appointed by God to rule.
questions.explanation: The 'Divine Right of Kings' was the idea that the king was directly appointed by God to rule.

questions.question: Which TWO chambers form the UK Parliament?
choices: House of Lords and House of Representatives
House of Fraser and House of Commons
House of Commons and House of Representatives
House of Lords and House of Commons
questions.explanation: The UK Parliament is formed by the House of Commons and the House of Lords.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following do pressure and lobby groups do?
choices: Organise violent protests and try to influence government policy
Assist MPs in their constituency work and represent the views of British business
Try to influence government policy and represent the views of British businesses
Organise violent protests and assist MPs in their constituency work
questions.explanation: Pressure and lobby groups are organisations which try to influence government policy. Some represent the views of British business. Others campaign on particular topics, such as the environment.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The Union Flag consists of four crosses, one for each part of the United Kingdom.
questions.explanation: The Union Flag consists of three crosses – the crosses of St George (England), St Andrew (Scotland) and St Patrick (Ireland).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: After the age of 70, drivers must renew their licence every three years.
After the age of 70, drivers must renew their licence every five years.
questions.explanation: Drivers can use their driving licence until they are 70 years old. After that, the licence is valid for three years at a time.

questions.question: Which TWO members of a family have a special day dedicated to them?
questions.explanation: In the UK, Mothering Sunday is celebrated on the Sunday three weeks before Easter and Father's Day on the third Sunday in June. Children send cards and give gifts on these days.

questions.question: When did the Battle of Hastings take place?
questions.explanation: The Battle of Hastings took place in 1066.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are responsibilities of Members of Parliament (MPs)?
choices: Representing everyone in their constituency and supporting the government on all decisions and laws
Scrutinising and commenting on what the government is doing and representing only those who voted for them
Scrutinising and commenting on what the government is doing and supporting the government on all decisions and laws
Representing everyone in their constituency and scrutinising and commenting on what the government is doing
questions.explanation: MPs have a number of different responsibilities, including representing everyone in their constituency, and scrutinising and commenting on what the government is doing.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
In 1588 the English defeated the Spanish Armada.
questions.explanation: In 1588, the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships), which had been sent by Spain to conquer England and restore Catholicism.

questions.question: Who first built the Tower of London?
questions.explanation:
The Tower of London was first built by William the Conqueror
after he became king in 1066.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The Roman army left England after 100 years to defend other parts of their Empire.
The Roman army left England after 400 years to defend other parts of their Empire.
questions.explanation: The Romans left England in AD 410 to defend other parts of their Empire. They had remained in Britain for 400 years.

questions.question: Which TWO are famous British fashion designers?
choices: Capability Brown and Sir Edwin Lutyens
questions.explanation: Britain has produced many great designers. Leading fashion designers of recent years include Mary Quant, Alexander McQueen and Vivienne Westwood.

questions.question: In 1776, 13 British colonies declared their independence. In which part of the world were these colonies?
questions.explanation:
In 1776, 13 American colonies declared their independence,
stating that people had a right to establish their own governments.
The colonists eventually defeated the British army and Britain
recognised the colonies’ independence in 1783.

questions.question: Which language was spoken by people during the Iron Age?
choices: A language that was part of the Celtic family
questions.explanation: The language Iron Age people spoke was part of the Celtic language family.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are examples of criminal law?
choices: Disputes about faulty goods and discrimination in the workplace
Racial crime and discrimination in the workplace
Racial crime and disputes about faulty goods
Racial crime and selling tobacco to anyone under the age of 18
questions.explanation: Criminal law relates to crimes, which are usually investigated by the police or another authority such as a council, and which are punished by the courts. Examples of crimes include racial crime and selling tobacco to anyone under the age of 18.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The official name of the UK is the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.
The official name of the UK is Great Britain.
questions.explanation: The official name of the UK is the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

questions.question: Which TWO people are famous UK sports stars?
choices: Sir Chris Hoy and Dame Kelly Holmes
Dame Kelly Holmes and Jane Austen
Sir Chris Hoy and Lucien Freud
questions.explanation: Sir Chris Hoy is a Scottish cyclist who has won six gold and one silver Olympic medals. Dame Kelly Holmes won two gold medals for running in the 2004 Olympic Games.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The Battle of Britain in 1940 was fought at sea.
The Battle of Britain in 1940 was fought in the air.
questions.explanation:
The Battle of Britain was fought in the air above Britain in 1940. The British resisted with their fighter
planes and eventually won the crucial aerial battle against the
Germans, in the summer of 1940.

questions.question: The Enlightenment led to major developments in which TWO areas?
questions.explanation: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, science and philosophy developed. This is often called ‘the Enlightenment'.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Participating in your community is a fundamental principle of British life.
questions.explanation: British society is founded on fundamental values and principles which all those living in the UK should respect and support. This includes participating in community life.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: To apply to become a permanent resident or naturalised citizen of the UK, you must have a UK bank account.
To apply to become a permanent resident or naturalised citizen of the UK, you must be able to speak and read English.
questions.explanation: To apply to become a permanent resident or naturalised citizen of the UK, you must be able to speak and read English. You must also have a good understanding of life in the UK.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The King is ceremonial head of the Commonwealth.
The King is ceremonial head of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
questions.explanation: The King is the ceremonial head of the Commonwealth, which currently has 54 member states.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The first professional UK football clubs were formed in the late 19th century
The first professional UK football clubs were formed in 1066.
questions.explanation: Football has a long history in the UK and the first professional football clubs were formed in the late 19th century.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Emmeline Pankhurst is famous for her role in the campaign to give women the vote in parliamentary elections in the UK.
questions.explanation: Emmeline Pankhurst (1858–1928) helped found the Women’s Social and Political Union (WSPU). This was the first group whose members were called ‘suffragettes’. The group used civil disobedience as part of their protest to gain the vote for women.

questions.question: Which TWO values are upheld by the Commonwealth association of countries?
questions.explanation: The Commonwealth is based on the core values of democracy, good government and the rule of law.

questions.question: What is the aim of the United Nations?
choices: To create a single free trade market
To prevent war and promote international peace and security
To examine decisions made by the European Union
questions.explanation: The UK is part of the United Nations (UN), an international organisation with more than 190 countries as members. The UN was set up after the Second World War and aims to prevent war and promote international peace and security.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The Industrial Revolution is the name given to the rapid development of industry in Britain in the 20th century.
The Industrial Revolution is the name given to the rapid development of industry that began in the 18th century.
questions.explanation: The Industrial Revolution refers to the rapid development of industry in Britain from the mid-18th century.

questions.question: For approximately how many years did the Romans remain in Britain?
questions.explanation: The Romans remained in Britain for almost 400 years, from AD 43 to AD 410.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Hereditary peers have the automatic right to attend the House of Lords.
questions.explanation: Since 1999, hereditary peers have lost the automatic right to attend the House of Lords. They now elect a few of their number to represent them.

questions.question: Which is the most popular sport in the UK?
questions.explanation: Football is the UK's most popular sport. It has a long history in the UK and the first professional football clubs were formed in the late 19th century.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Most people in the UK live in towns and cities.
questions.explanation:
Most people live in towns and cities but much of Britain is
still countryside.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following countries are members of the Commonwealth?
questions.explanation: Australia and Canada are members of the Commonwealth. The King is the ceremonial head of the Commonwealth, which currently has 54 member states.

questions.question: On which date is St Patrick's Day celebrated?
questions.explanation: St Patrick, the patron saint of Northern Ireland (and Ireland), has a special day on 17 March.

questions.question: Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?                                                                                                     All people in the UK are expected to help the police prevent and detect crimes whenever they can.
questions.explanation: All people in the UK are expected to help the police prevent and detect crimes whenever they can.

questions.question: Which TWO responsibilities do you have as a resident of the UK?
choices: Respect and obey the law, and take in and look after wild animals
Treat others with fairness and vote for the government in power
Treat others with fairness, and take in and look after wild animals
Respect and obey the law and treat others with fairness
questions.explanation: There are responsibilities and freedoms which are shared by all those living in the UK. These include respecting and obeying the law, and treating others with fairness.

questions.question: Who do some local councils appoint as a ceremonial leader?
choices: A member of the Royal Family
questions.explanation: Many local authorities appoint a mayor, who is the ceremonial leader of the council. (In some towns, a mayor is elected to be the effective leader of the administration.)

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Henry VIII is famous for marrying six times and breaking away from the Church of Rome.
questions.explanation: Henry VIII had six wives and broke away from the Roman Catholic Church when the Pope refused to grant him a divorce so he could marry again.

questions.question: Which TWO issues can the devolved administrations pass laws on?
questions.explanation: The devolved administrations in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland can pass laws on matters that directly affect them, including health and education.

questions.question: By joining a political party, what TWO activities might you be involved in?
choices: Violent clashes with other political parties, and handing out leaflets in the street
Joining your MPs for sessions in the House of Commons, and handing out leaflets in the street
Handing out leaflets in the street, and knocking on people's doors asking for support
Joining your MP for sessions in the House of Commons, and knocking on people's doors and asking for support
questions.explanation: Political parties welcome new members. Members work hard to persuade people to vote for their candidates – for instance, by handing out leaflets in the street or by knocking on people's doors and asking for their support. This is called 'canvassing'.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
In the UK, there are now a record number of people aged 85 and over.
questions.explanation: People in the UK are living longer than ever before. There are now a record number of people aged 85 and over.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Wales and Northern Ireland each have their own Church of state.
There is no established Church in Wales or Northern Ireland.
questions.explanation: There is no established Church in Wales or Northern Ireland.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
A public vote in 2002 decided that Winston Churchill was the greatest Briton of all time.
questions.explanation: In 2002, Winston Churchill (1874–1965) was voted the greatest Briton of all time by the public.

questions.question: What system of government does the UK have?
questions.explanation: The system of government in the UK is a parliamentary democracy. The UK is divided into parliamentary constituencies, and voters in each constituency elect a Member of Parliament (MP) to represent them.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The UK is governed by the parliament sitting in Westminster.
The UK is governed by the parliament sitting in Edinburgh.
questions.explanation: The UK is governed by the parliament sitting in Westminster. Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland also have parliaments or assemblies of their own, with devolved powers in defined areas.

questions.question: Which TWO new national bodies began operating in 1999?
choices: Welsh Assembly (now called the Senedd) and Scottish Parliament
House of Lords and Welsh Assembly (now called the Senedd)
House of Lords and Scottish Parliament
questions.explanation: Since 1997, some powers have been devolved from the central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them. There has been a Welsh Assembly (now called the Senedd) and a Scottish Parliament since 1999.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following were British inventions?
questions.explanation: The television and jet engine are two of many important inventions by Britons in the 20th century.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
In 1833 the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire.
questions.explanation: In 1833 the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire.

questions.question: What is the name of the Northern Ireland Assembly building?
questions.explanation: The Northern Ireland Assembly building is known as Stormont.

questions.question: What happens when Members of Parliament (MPs) hold surgeries?
choices: Local councillors meet their MP to discuss local issues
Members of the public meet their MP to discuss issues
MPs meet doctors to discuss local health issues
MPs meet the press to discuss national issues
questions.explanation: Many MPs hold regular local ‘surgeries’, where constituents can go in person to talk about issues that are of concern to them.

questions.question: Where did the Vikings come from?
questions.explanation: The Vikings first raided Britain in AD 789. They came from Denmark, Norway and Sweden.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Sake Dean Mahomet is famous for introducing tea-drinking and bungalows to Britain from India.
Sake Dean Mahomet is famous for introducing curry houses to Britain from India.
questions.explanation: Sake Dean Mahomet (1759–1851) opened the first curry house in Britain in 1810.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The Civil War between Charles I and Parliament in the mid-17th century led to Oliver Cromwell becoming king of England.
questions.explanation: At the end of the Civil War, England became a republic and Oliver Cromwell was given the title of Lord Protector.

questions.question: Where is the Welsh Parliament (the Senedd) based?
questions.explanation: The Welsh Parliament (the Senedd) is based in Cardiff, the capital city of Wales.

questions.question: What did St Augustine and St Columba do during the Anglo-Saxon period?
choices: They led an uprising in Wales.
They helped to spread Christianity across Britain.
They fought courageously against the Romans.
questions.explanation: St Augustine and St Columba were early Christian missionaries who came to Britain to preach about Christianity. St Columba founded a monastery on the Isle of Iona. St Augustine spread Christianity in the south and became the first Archbishop of Canterbury.

questions.question: Which TWO of these novels are by Charles Dickens?
choices: Harry Potter, and Pride and Prejudice
Pride and Prejudice, and Oliver Twist
questions.explanation: Charles Dickens wrote a number of very famous novels, including Oliver Twist and Great Expectations.

questions.question: Which TWO are influential British bands?
choices: The National Trust and The Rolling Stones
The National Trust and The Beatles
The Rolling Stones and The Beatles
The Rolling Stones and The Royal Family
questions.explanation: The Beatles and The Rolling Stones are two influential British bands that continue to have an influence on music both in the UK and abroad.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Mary, Queen of Scots was unrelated to Queen Elizabeth I.
Mary, Queen of Scots was a cousin of Queen Elizabeth I.
questions.explanation: Mary was Elizabeth I’s cousin. She was eventually executed, accused of plotting against Elizabeth I.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The official home of the Prime Minister is 10 Downing Street.
The official home of the Prime Minister is Buckingham Palace.
questions.explanation: The official home of the Prime Minister is 10 Downing Street, in central London, near the Houses of Parliament. He or she also has a country house outside London called Chequers.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following would you contact for help on a legal matter?
choices: A solicitor and a local councillor
A local councillor and your local Member of Parliament (MP)
Citizens Advice and your local Member of Parliament (MP)
questions.explanation:
Solicitors are trained lawyers who give advice on legal matters, take
action for their clients and represent their clients in court. Citizens Advice can give you names of local solicitors and tell you which areas of law they specialise in.

questions.question: Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE? British scientists were the first to clone a mammal successfully.
questions.explanation: True - the British team were the first to succeed in cloning a mammal, Dolly the sheep.

questions.question: Why is 1918 an important date in the history of women's rights?
choices: The first divorce laws were introduced.
Women over the age of 30 were given voting rights.
Women were made legally responsible for their children.
questions.explanation: In 1918, women over the age of 30 were given voting rights. In 1928, women were given the right to vote at the age of 21, the same as men.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are Christian festivals celebrated in the UK?
questions.explanation: Easter and Christmas are two Christian festivals. Christmas celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ, and Easter marks his death on Good Friday and his rising from the dead on Easter Sunday.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Forcing another person to marry is a criminal offence in the UK.
questions.explanation: Forced marriage is where one or both parties do not or cannot give their consent to enter into the partnership. This is a criminal offence in the UK.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: In the UK, pregnant women have the same right to work as anyone else.
In the UK, employers have the right not to employ pregnant women.
questions.explanation: UK laws ensure people are not treated unfairly in any area of life or work because of their age, disability, sex, pregnancy and maternity, race, religion or belief, sexuality or marital status.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Florence Nightingale is associated with policing.
Florence Nightingale is associated with nursing.
questions.explanation: Florence Nightingale treated soldiers who were fighting in the Crimean War. She later established the Nightingale Training School for nurses at St Thomas' Hospital in London. She is often regarded as the founder of modern nursing.

questions.question: Which TWO patron saints' days occur in March?
questions.explanation: St David, the patron saint of Wales, has a special day on 1 March. St Patrick, the patron saint of Northern Ireland (and Ireland), has a special day on 17 March.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are famous Paralympians?
choices: Ellie Simmonds and Baroness Tanni Grey-Thompson
Ellie Simmonds and Dame Ellen MacArthur
Dame Jessica Ennis-Hill and Baroness Tanni Grey-Thompson
Dame Jessica Ennis-Hill and Dame Ellen MacArthur
questions.explanation: Ellie Simmonds won gold medals for swimming at the 2008, 2012 and 2016 Paralympic Games. Baroness Tanni Grey-Thompson is an athlete who uses a wheelchair and won 16 Paralympic medals.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
If an accused person is aged 18 to 21, their case will be heard in a Youth Court.
questions.explanation: If an accused person is aged 10 to 17, the case is normally held in a Youth Court.

questions.question: In 1348 a third of the populations of England, Wales and Scotland died as a result of which plague?
questions.explanation:
In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain.
This was known as the Black Death. One third of the population of
England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales. This was one of the worst disasters ever to strike Britain.

questions.question: Which TWO are plays by William Shakespeare?
choices: A Midsummer Night's Dream, and Oliver Twist
Romeo and Juliet, and Oliver Twist
A Midsummer Night's Dream, and Romeo and Juliet
Pride and Prejudice, and Romeo and Juliet
questions.explanation: Among the many plays that Shakespeare wrote are A Midsummer Night's Dream and Romeo and Juliet.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The official church of state in England is the Church of England.
There is no official church of state in England.
questions.explanation: The Church of England is the official church of state in England. The monarch is the head of the Church of England.

questions.question: Who invaded England in 1066?
questions.explanation: In 1066, William, the Duke of Normandy, invaded England and defeated King Harold at the Battle of Hastings.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE OR FALSE?
The National Citizen Service provides military training to young people.
questions.explanation: The National Citizen Service gives 16- and 17-year-olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills and take part in a community project.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: In 1776, 13 American colonies declared their independence from Britain.
The American colonists were eventually defeated by the British.
questions.explanation: In 1776, 13 American colonies declared their independence from Britain, stating that people had a right to establish their own governments.

questions.question: Which TWO were 20th-century British discoveries or inventions?
questions.explanation: The hovercraft was invented by Sir Christopher Cockerell and penicillin was discovered by Sir Alexander Fleming.

questions.question: Which TWO families contested the Wars of the Roses in the 15th century?
choices: The House of York and the House of Windsor
The House of Windsor and the House of Lancaster
The House of Tudor and the House of Windsor
The House of York and the House of Lancaster
questions.explanation: A civil war known as the Wars of the Roses broke out in 1455 between supporters of the House of Lancaster and the House of York. It ended in 1485 at the Battle of Bosworth Field, when King Richard III of the House of York was killed.

questions.question: Which UK city hosted the 2012 Paralympic Games?
questions.explanation: The Paralympic Games for 2012 were hosted in London.

questions.question: Once you are aged 17, which TWO vehicles can you learn to drive?
choices: Motor cycle and heavy goods vehicle
questions.explanation: In the UK, you must be at least 17 years old to drive a car or motor cycle and you must have a driving licence to drive on public roads.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Proceedings in Parliament cannot be reported in the press.
Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television.
questions.explanation: Proceedings in Parliament are broadcast on television and published in official reports called Hansard. Most people get information about political issues and events from newspapers (often called ‘the press’), television, radio and the internet.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The Channel Islands have their own governments.
questions.explanation: The Channel Islands have their own governments and are called 'Crown dependencies'.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: There is a yearly sailing race on the River Thames between Oxford and Cambridge universities.
There is a yearly rowing race on the River Thames between Oxford and Cambridge universities.
questions.explanation: Rowing is a popular sport in the UK, both as a leisure activity and as a competitive sport. There is a popular yearly race on the River Thames between Oxford and Cambridge universities.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are fundamental principles of British life?
choices: Only driving your car on weekdays and participation in community life
Participation in community life and tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs
Only driving your car on weekdays and growing your own fruit and vegetables
Growing your own fruit and vegetables and tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs
questions.explanation: British society is founded on fundamental values and principles which all those living in the UK should respect and support. These include participation in community life and tolerance of those with different faiths and beliefs.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Members of Parliament (MPs) are elected through a system called 'first past the post'.
MPs are elected through a system called 'proportional representation'.
questions.explanation: MPs are elected through a system called 'first past the post'. This means that in each constituency, the candidate who gets the most votes is elected.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are major horse-racing events in the UK?
choices: The Open Championship and the Scottish Grand National
The Open Championship and the Six Nations Championship
Scottish Grand National and the Six Nations Championship
Scottish Grand National and Royal Ascot
questions.explanation: Famous horse-racing events include: Royal Ascot, a five-day race meeting in Berkshire attended by members of the Royal Family; and the Scottish Grand National at Ayr.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: A free press means that what is written in newspapers is free from government control.
A free press means that newspapers are given out free of charge.
questions.explanation: The UK has a free press. This means that what is written in newspapers is free from government control.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The criminal court systems in England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland are identical.
questions.explanation: There are some differences between the criminal court systems in different parts of the UK.

questions.question: When walking your dog in a public place, what must you ensure?
choices: That your dog wears a special dog coat
That your dog never strays more than 3 metres away from you
That your dog does not come into contact with other dogs
That your dog wears a collar showing the name and address of the owner
questions.explanation: All dogs in public places must wear a collar showing the name and address of the owner.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Plymouth, Norwich and Leeds are cities in England.
Newport, Swansea and Cardiff are cities in Scotland.
questions.explanation: Plymouth, Norwich and Leeds are cities in England.

questions.question: Which of these is a fundamental principle of British life?
choices: Actively supporting your local football team
questions.explanation: Participation in community life is one of the fundamental values and principles which all those living in the UK should respect and support.

questions.question: Why was the Habeas Corpus Act of 1679 so important?
choices: It ensured no person could be held prisoner unlawfully.
It allowed people to bury the dead where they wished.
It ensured that those who died could only be buried by a relative.
It ended capital punishment in England.
questions.explanation:
The Habeas Corpus Act was a very 
important piece of legislation which remains relevant today. Habeas corpus is Latin for ‘you must present the person in court’. The Act guaranteed that no one could be held prisoner unlawfully.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: In a Crown Court case, the judge decides the penalty when someone is found guilty.
In a Crown Court case, the jury decides the penalty when someone is found guilty.
questions.explanation: If the jury in a Crown Court case finds the defendant guilty, the judge decides on the penalty.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: People in paid work need to pay National Insurance Contributions.
People in paid work do not need to pay National Insurance Contributions.
questions.explanation: Almost everybody in the UK who is in paid work must pay National Insurance Contributions. Employees have their National Insurance Contributions deducted from their pay by their employer.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Ireland is part of the UK.
questions.explanation:
The UK is made up of England, Scotland, Wales and Northern
Ireland. The rest of Ireland is an independent country.

questions.question: Dunkirk is associated with which TWO events?
choices: The fall of Singapore and small boats coming to the rescue
The D-Day landings and the fall of Singapore
The rescue of 300,000 men and small boats coming to the rescue
The fall of Singapore and the rescue of 300,000 men
questions.explanation: In 1940, many civilian volunteers in small pleasure and fishing boats from Britain helped the Navy to rescue 300,000 men from the beaches around Dunkirk. The evacuation gave rise to the phrase ‘the Dunkirk spirit’.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are Christian groups?
questions.explanation: Roman Catholics and Baptists are Christian groups. Baptists are a Protestant Christian group. Other Protestant groups include the Church of England, Methodists, Presbyterians and Quakers.

questions.question: Dylan Thomas was a famous writer and poet from which country?
questions.explanation: Dylan Thomas, who lived from 1914 until 1953, was a Welsh poet and writer. One of his most well-known works is Under Milk Wood.

questions.question: Which event is remembered on 5 November each year?
choices: The end of the Second World War
A plan to blow up the Houses of Parliament in 1605
The defeat of the Spanish Armada in 1588
questions.explanation: Bonfire Night, 5 November, is an occasion when people in Great Britain set off fireworks at home or in special displays. The origin of this celebration was an event in 1605, when a group of Catholics led by Guy Fawkes failed in their plan to kill the Protestant king with a bomb in the Houses of Parliament.

questions.question: Who were the 'suffragettes'?
choices: Women who left the UK to live in America
Women who campaigned for women's votes
Women who left their jobs when they got married
Women who stayed at home to raise a family
questions.explanation:
In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, an increasing number of women campaigned and demonstrated for women's rights, in particular the right to vote. They formed the women’s suffrage movement and became known
as ‘suffragettes’.

questions.question: Which of the following is a Stone Age monument in the UK?
questions.explanation: Stonehenge is a Stone Age monument in the English county of Wiltshire. It was probably a special gathering place for seasonal ceremonies.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Civil servants have to be politically aligned to the elected government.
questions.explanation:
Civil servants are chosen on merit
and are politically neutral – they are not political appointees.

questions.question: For which TWO types of literature is William Shakespeare famous?
questions.explanation: William Shakespeare was a famous playwright and sonnet writer.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Most shops in the UK open seven days a week.
All shops in the UK close on Sundays.
questions.explanation: Most shops in the UK open seven days a week, although trading hours on Sundays and public holidays are generally reduced.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The jet engine and radar were developed in Britain in the 1830s.
questions.explanation: The jet engine and the radar were both developed in Britain in the 1930s.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are linked to football?
choices: The Premier League and The Open
questions.explanation:
The English Premier League attracts a huge international
audience. Many of the best players in the world play in the Premier League. Many UK teams also compete in competitions such as the UEFA (Union of European Football Associations) Champions League, against other teams from Europe.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following wars were English kings involved in during the Middle Ages?
choices: The Crusades and the First World War
The Crimean War and the Crusades
The Crimean War and the Hundred Years War
The Crusades and the Hundred Years War
questions.explanation:
During the Middle Ages, the English kings fought a number
of wars abroad. Many knights took part in the Crusades, in which
European Christians fought for control of the Holy Land. English
kings also fought a long war with France, called the Hundred
Years War (even though it actually lasted 116 years).

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The flower that is particularly associated with England is the rose.
questions.explanation:
The countries that make up the UK
all have flowers which are particularly associated with them and which are sometimes worn on national saints’ days. In England, the flower is the rose.

questions.question: Textile and engineering firms found workers from which TWO countries after the Second World War?
questions.explanation: Textile and engineering firms from the north of England and the Midlands sent agents to India and Pakistan to find workers.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The First World War ended at 11.00 am on 11 November 1918.
questions.explanation: The First World War ended at 11.00 am on 11th November 1918 with victory for Britain and its allies.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
In the 1830s and 1840s a group called the Chartists campaigned for reform to the voting system.
questions.explanation: The Chartists campaigned for reform of the voting system. The changes they wanted included elections every year and for all regions to be equal in the electoral system.

questions.question: Which of the following is part of the UK?
questions.explanation: Northern Ireland is part of the UK, along with England, Wales and Scotland.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Charles Dickens was famous for writing musicals.
questions.explanation: Charles Dickens wrote a number of famous novels, including Oliver Twist and Great Expectations.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: National parks are areas of protected countryside that everyone can visit.
National parks are national sports stadiums for people to hold sporting events.
questions.explanation: National parks are areas of protected countryside that everyone can visit, and where people live, work and look after the landscape. There are 15 national parks in England, Wales and Scotland.

questions.question: Which jubilee did Queen Elizabeth II celebrate in 2012?
questions.explanation: Queen Elizabeth II reigned from 1952 until her death in 2022. In 2012 she celebrated her Diamond Jubilee (60 years as Queen).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The BBC is primarily funded by advertising.
The BBC is partially funded by the state.
questions.explanation: The BBC is a British public service broadcaster providing television and radio programmes. Although it receives some state funding, it is independent of the government.

questions.question: Which TWO groups were associated with King Charles I and Parliament during the English Civil War?
questions.explanation: Supporters of the king were known as Cavaliers and supporters of Parliament were known as Roundheads.

questions.question: Which TWO are political parties in the UK?
questions.explanation: The major political parties in the UK include the Conservative Party, the Labour Party and the Liberal Democrats.

questions.question: In which part of the British Empire did the Boer War of 1899–1902 take place?
questions.explanation: The Boer War took place in South Africa between the British army and the Boer settlers, who originally came from the Netherlands.

questions.question: Which TWO are 20th-century British inventions?
choices: The World Wide Web and the diesel engine
Television and the World Wide Web
Mobile phones and the diesel engine
questions.explanation: Television was developed by John Logie Baird in the 1920s. Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web in 1990.

questions.question: Why was the Magna Carta important?
choices: It gave all men the vote.
It restricted the power of the monarch.
It established a system of free education.
questions.explanation: King John was forced by his noblemen to agree to a number of demands. The result was a charter of rights called the Magna Carta, which restricted the king's power to collect taxes or to make or change laws.

questions.question: What task is associated with the National Trust?
questions.explanation:
Many parts of the countryside and places of interest are kept open
by the National Trust in England, Wales and Northern Ireland and
the National Trust for Scotland. Both are charities that work to
preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside in the
UK.

questions.question: Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?                                                                               'We shall fight on the beaches' is a famous quote from a speech by Queen Elizabeth I about the Spanish Armada.
questions.explanation: 'We shall fight on the beaches' is a quote from a speech by Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister,  after the evacuation of Dunkirk in 1940.

questions.question: In everyday language, people may say 'rain stopped play'. With which sport is this phrase associated?
questions.explanation: The expression 'rain stopped play' is associated with cricket. The phrase has now passed into everyday usage.

questions.question: Which TWO are famous horse-racing events?
choices: The Cup Final and the Six Nations
The Grand National and Royal Ascot
Royal Ascot and the Six Nations
The Grand National and the Cup Final
questions.explanation: Famous horse-racing events include: Royal Ascot, a five-day race meeting in Berkshire attended by members of the Royal Family; the Grand National at Aintree near Liverpool; and the Scottish Grand National at Ayr.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are famous British artists?
choices: David Hockney and Sir Edward Elgar
Sir Edward Elgar and Henry Moore
Sir Andy Murray and Sir Edward Elgar
questions.explanation: David Hockney was an important contributor to the 'pop art' movement of the 1960s. Henry Moore is best known for his large bronze abstract sculptures.

questions.question: Which queen is remembered for fighting against the Romans?
questions.explanation:
One of the tribal leaders who fought against the Romans was Boudicca, the queen of the Iceni in what is now eastern England. She is still remembered today and there is
a statue of her on Westminster Bridge in London, near the Houses
of Parliament.

questions.question: What is a jury made up of?
choices: People randomly chosen from the electoral register
People who are members of political parties
People who have submitted an application form and been accepted
questions.explanation: A jury is made up of members of the public chosen at random from the local electoral register.

questions.question: Who elects Police and Crime Commissioners (PCCs)?
questions.explanation: The public elects Police and Crime Commissioners (PCCs) in England and Wales. PCCs are responsible for the delivery of an efficient and effective police force.

questions.question: Which group of refugees settled in England between 1680 and 1720?
questions.explanation: Between 1680 and 1720 many refugees called Huguenots came from France. They were Protestants and had been persecuted for their religion.

questions.question: Which significant change was introduced by the Education Act of 1944?
choices: Free secondary education in England and Wales
The requirement to wear school uniform
questions.explanation: The Education Act of 1944 (also called 'The Butler Act' after the Minister of Education at the time, R A Butler) introduced free secondary education in England and Wales.

questions.question: Which festival is celebrated on 31 October?
questions.explanation: Halloween is celebrated on 31 October.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Snowdonia is a national park in Northern Ireland.
questions.explanation: Snowdonia is a national park in North Wales. Its most well-known landmark is Snowdon, which is the highest mountain in Wales.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
People are able to buy National Lottery tickets in the UK if they are aged 14 or over.
questions.explanation: People under 18 are not allowed to participate in the National Lottery.

questions.question: Which court would you use to get back money that was owed to you?
questions.explanation:
County Courts deal with a wide range of civil disputes. These
include people trying to get back money that is owed to them.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Before 1215 there were few formal limits to the power of the king of England.
questions.explanation:
There were few formal limits to the king’s power until 1215. In that year, King John was forced by his noblemen to agree to a number of demands. The result was a charter of rights called the Magna Carta
(which means the Great Charter). The Magna Carta established the
idea that even the king was subject to the law.

questions.question: Why was Henry VIII an important English monarch?
choices: He broke from the Church of Rome.
He re-established the Catholic Church in England.
questions.explanation: Henry VIII broke from the Catholic Church of Rome when the Pope refused to let him divorce his first wife. Henry established the Church of England. In this new Church, the king, not the Pope, had the power to appoint bishops and order how people should worship.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Margaret Thatcher was the longest-serving UK Prime Minister of the 20th century.
questions.explanation: Margaret Thatcher was the longest-serving Prime Minister of the 20th century. She won her first General Election in 1979 and was re-elected in 1983 and 1987. She left office in 1990.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following issues can the Northern Ireland Assembly make decisions on?
questions.explanation: The Northern Ireland Assembly can make decisions on various issues, including agriculture and social services.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Cardiff, Swansea and Newport are cities in England.
questions.explanation: Cardiff, Swansea and Newport are all cities in Wales.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
King Henry VIII established the Church of England when the Pope refused to grant him a divorce.
questions.explanation: To divorce his first wife (Catherine of Aragon), Henry needed the approval of the Pope. When the Pope refused, Henry established the Church of England. In this new Church, the king, not the Pope, would have the power to appoint bishops and order how people should worship.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
St Helena is a Crown dependency.
questions.explanation: St Helena is a British overseas territory and not a Crown dependency.

questions.question: How old must you be to ride a moped in the UK?
questions.explanation: In the UK you need to be at least 16 years old to ride a moped.

questions.question: What important change to our voting rights took place in 1969?
choices: Women over 35 were given the vote.
The voting age was reduced to 18 for men and women.
questions.explanation: In 1969, the voting age was reduced to 18 for men and women.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Shakespeare was a playwright and actor.
questions.explanation:
Shakespeare was born in
Stratford-upon-Avon, England. He
was a playwright and actor and
wrote many poems and plays.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England united under King Alfred the Great.
The Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England united under King Kenneth MacAlpin.
questions.explanation: The Anglo-Saxon kingdoms in England united under King Alfred the Great, who defeated the Vikings.

questions.question: What is the role of a jury at a court trial?
choices: To decide whether evidence should be allowed to be heard
To decide the sentence that the accused should be given
To decide who the judge should be
To decide a verdict based on what they have heard.
questions.explanation: A jury has to listen to the evidence presented at the trial and then decide a verdict of ‘guilty’ or ‘not guilty’ based on what they have heard. In Scotland, a third verdict of ‘not proven’ is also possible. If the jury finds a defendant guilty, the judge decides on the penalty.

questions.question: Which cross on the Union Flag represents the patron saint of England?
questions.explanation: The cross of St George, patron saint of England, is an upright red cross on a white ground.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The Reform Act of 1832 greatly increased the number of people who had the right to vote.
The Reform Act of 1832 increased the power of the House of Lords.
questions.explanation: The Reform Act of 1832 greatly increased the number of people with the right to vote. The Act also abolished the old pocket and rotten boroughs (parliamentary seats where there were few voters) and more parliamentary seats were given to the towns and cities.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: A famous sailing event is held at Cowes on the Isle of Wight.
A famous sailing event is held in the city of Norwich.
questions.explanation: Many sailing events are held throughout the UK, the most famous of which is at Cowes on the Isle of Wight.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: When you apply to become a UK citizen or permanent resident, you can choose which laws and responsibilities you want to accept.
When you apply to become a UK citizen or permanent resident, you will be agreeing to respect the laws, values and traditions of the UK.
questions.explanation: Applying to become a permanent resident or citizen of the UK is an important decision and commitment. You will be agreeing to accept the responsibilities which go with permanent residence and to respect the laws, values and traditions of the UK.

questions.question: What is one of the roles of school governors?
choices: Setting the strategic direction of the school
Giving teachers ideas for lesson plans
Serving food and drink in the canteen
questions.explanation: School governors have an important part to play in raising school standards. This includes setting the strategic direction of the school.

questions.question: What must you do in order to vote in elections?
choices: Pay income tax in the year before the election
Put your name on the electoral register
Register your identity with the police
questions.explanation: To be able to vote in a parliamentary or local election, you must have your name on the electoral register. You can register by contacting your local council electoral registration office.

questions.question: What happened to Margaret Thatcher in 1979 to make her famous in UK history?
choices: She took part in the Olympics.
She became a High Court judge.
She became the first woman Prime Minister.
She was made a general in the British army.
questions.explanation:
Following the Conservative victory in the General Election in
1979, Margaret Thatcher became the first woman Prime Minister
of the UK. She was the longest-serving Prime Minister of the
20th century, remaining in office until 1990.

questions.question: At what age can you vote in a General Election in the UK?
questions.explanation: The present voting age of 18 was set in 1969.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Baptists, Methodists and Quakers are denominations of the Roman Catholic Church.
Baptists, Methodists, and Quakers are Protestant Christian groups.
questions.explanation: Baptists, Methodists and Quakers are Protestant Christian groups.

questions.question: Which TWO are famous UK landmarks?
questions.explanation: Snowdonia is a national park in North Wales. Loch Lomond is the largest expanse of fresh water in mainland Britain and probably the best-known part of the Trossachs National Park.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following is William Shakespeare famous for writing?
questions.explanation:
William Shakespeare (1564–1616) was a playwright and actor. His plays and poems are still performed and studied
in Britain and other countries today.

questions.question: During the 'Great Depression' of the 1930s, which TWO major new industries developed?
questions.explanation: During the Great Depression of the 1930s, many traditional heavy industries, such as shipbuilding, went into decline. However, new industries - such as aviation and the automobile industry - developed.

questions.question: What are Beowulf, The Tyger and She Walks in Beauty?
questions.explanation: Beowulf is an Anglo-Saxon poem, The Tyger is a poem by William Blake, and She Walks in Beauty is a poem by Lord Byron.

questions.question: Which of the following is a traditional pub game in the UK?
questions.explanation: Pool and darts are traditional pub games. Pub quizzes are also popular.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are traditional British foods?
questions.explanation: Welsh cakes are a traditional Welsh snack made from flour, dried fruits and spices. Haggis, a traditional Scottish food, is a sheep's stomach stuffed with offal, suet, onions and oatmeal.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The capital city of Northern Ireland is Swansea.
The capital city of Northern Ireland is Belfast.
questions.explanation: The capital city of Northern Ireland is Belfast.

questions.question: Which of the following is a traditional food associated with Scotland?
questions.explanation: Haggis is a traditional Scottish food. It is a sheep’s stomach stuffed with offal, suet, onions and oatmeal.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The Industrial Revolution was the rapid development of industry in the 18th and 19th centuries.
The Industrial Revolution introduced changes in the banking system in the 1970s.
questions.explanation: The Industrial Revolution was the rapid development of industry in Britain in the 18th and 19th centuries. The development of machinery and use of steam power transformed industries such as manufacturing and mining.

questions.question: What do Sir William Golding, Seamus Heaney and Harold Pinter have in common?
choices: They were all famous British athletes.
They were part of the first British expedition to the North Pole.
They have all won the Nobel Prize in Literature.
questions.explanation: Several British writers, including the novelist Sir William Golding, the poet Seamus Heaney, and the playwright Harold Pinter, have won the Nobel Prize in Literature.

questions.question: When is Boxing Day?
questions.explanation: Boxing Day is the day after Christmas Day and is a public holiday.

questions.question: In the 19th century, the UK produced more than half the world's supply of one of these products. Which one?
questions.explanation: In the 19th century the UK produced more than half of the world's supplies of iron, coal and cotton cloth.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Big Ben is a mountain in eastern England
Big Ben is the nickname for the great bell of the clock at the Houses of Parliament.
questions.explanation:
Big Ben is the nickname for the great bell of the clock at the Houses of Parliament in London. Many people call the clock Big
Ben as well.

questions.question: Which Scottish king defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn in 1314?
questions.explanation: The English were defeated at the Battle of Bannockburn by Robert the Bruce in 1314.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The civil service largely consists of political appointees.
The civil service is politically neutral.
questions.explanation:
Civil servants support the government in developing and
implementing its policies. They are chosen on merit and are politically neutral – they are not political appointees.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
In 1707 the kingdoms of England and Scotland were united.
questions.explanation:
The Act of Union, known as the
Treaty of Union in Scotland, was agreed in 1707 and created
the Kingdom of Great Britain.

questions.question: Which TWO things can you do to look after the environment?
choices: Recycle your waste and never turn your lights off in your house
Drive your car as much as possible and never turn the lights off in your house
Recycle your waste and walk and use public transport to get around
Drive your car as much as possible and recycle your waste
questions.explanation: It is important to recycle as much of your waste as you can, so the amount of rubbish being put into landfill is reduced. Walking and using public transport to get around when you can is also a good way to protect the environment.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: In Elizabeth I’s time, English settlers began to colonise Australia.
In Elizabeth I’s time, English settlers began to colonise the eastern coast of America.
questions.explanation: In Elizabeth I’s time, English settlers first began to colonise the eastern coast of America.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: All Acts of Parliament are made in the monarch's name.
All Acts of Parliament are made in the Prime Minister's name.
questions.explanation: The monarch is the head of state of the UK. All Acts of Parliament are made in the monarch's name.

questions.question: Which of the following is a Crown dependency?
questions.explanation: The Channel Islands are closely linked with the UK but are not part of it. These islands have their own governments and are called ‘Crown dependencies’.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Local elections are normally held in May.
Local elections are normally held in March.
questions.explanation: For most local authorities, local elections for councillors are held in May every year.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
If you are a Commonwealth citizen living in the UK, you can vote in all public elections.
questions.explanation: Adult citizens of the UK, and citizens of the Commonwealth and Ireland who are resident in the UK, can vote in all public elections.

questions.question: Which TWO are examples of civil law?
choices: Drugs law and racial crime law
Housing law and racial crime law
questions.explanation: Civil law is used to settle disputes between individuals or groups. Examples of civil law include housing law, employment law, consumer rights and laws related to the recovery of debt.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
There are many variations in language in the different parts of the UK.
questions.explanation: There are many variations in language in the different parts of the UK. The English language has many accents and dialects. In Wales, many people speak Welsh. In Scotland, Gaelic is spoken in some parts of the Highlands and Islands, and in Northern Ireland some people speak Irish Gaelic.

questions.question: Which of these is the name of a novel by Jane Austen?
questions.explanation: Jane Austen was an English novelist. Her books include Pride and Prejudice and Sense and Sensibility. Her novels are concerned with marriage and family relationships. Many have been made into television programmes or films.

questions.question: Which of the following is the capital city of Wales?
questions.explanation: The capital city of Wales is Cardiff.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following do you have to pay tax on?
choices: Income from property, savings and dividends, and small amounts of money given to you as a gift
Income from property, savings and dividends, and shopping vouchers given to you by family or friends
Profits from self-employment, and income from property, savings and dividends
Profits from self-employment, and shopping vouchers given to you by family or friends
questions.explanation: People in the UK have to pay tax on their income, which includes profits from self-employment, and income from property, savings and dividends. Money raised from income tax pays for government services such as roads, education, police and the armed forces.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Jane Austen and Charles Dickens were famous novelists.
Jane Austen and Charles Dickens were famous painters.
questions.explanation: Jane Austen and Charles Dickens were famous novelists. Jane Austen's books include Pride and Prejudice, and Sense and Sensibility. Charles Dickens's novels include Oliver Twist and Great Expectations.

questions.question: After slavery was abolished in the British Empire, more than 2 million migrants came from which TWO countries to replace the freed slaves?
questions.explanation: After 1833, 2 million Indian and Chinese workers were employed to replace the freed slaves.

questions.question: Which TWO courts deal with minor criminal cases in the UK?
choices: Justice of the Peace Court and Magistrates' Court
Justice of the Peace Court and Crown Court
questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, most minor criminal cases are dealt with in a Magistrates' Court. In Scotland, minor criminal offences go to a Justice of the Peace Court.

questions.question: Which of the following is a British overseas territory?
questions.explanation: There are several British overseas territories in other parts of the world, such as the Falkland Islands.

questions.question: Which TWO commemorations or celebrations are held in November each year?
questions.explanation:
Bonfire Night, 5 November, is an occasion when people in Great
Britain set off fireworks at home or in special displays. Remembrance Day, 11 November, commemorates those who died fighting for the UK and its allies.

questions.question: Henry VII established the House of Tudor. What colour rose became the Tudor emblem?
questions.explanation: The Tudor rose was a red rose with a white rose inside it, showing the alliance between the Houses of York and Lancaster, which had previously fought against each other.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Richard Arkwright developed new farming methods in the UK.
Richard Arkwright ran efficient and profitable factories.
questions.explanation: Richard Arkwright is remembered for the efficient and profitable way that he ran his factories.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Sir Isaac Newton was a famous musician from the 18th century.
questions.explanation: Sir Isaac Newton was a famous scientist who showed how gravity applied to the whole universe.

questions.question: At which festival are mince pies traditionally eaten?
questions.explanation: Christmas is celebrated in a traditional way. People usually spend the day at home and eat a special meal, which often includes roast turkey, Christmas pudding and mince pies.

questions.question: Which TWO rights are offered by the UK to citizens and permanent residents?
choices: Free groceries for everyone and a right to a fair trial
Long lunch breaks on Friday and a right to a fair trial
Freedom of speech and a right to a fair trial
Freedom of speech and free groceries for everyone
questions.explanation: There are responsibilities and freedoms which are shared by all those living in the UK. These include freedom of speech and a right to a fair trial.

questions.question: St George is the patron saint of which country?
questions.explanation: St George is the patron saint of England, and is celebrated on 23rd of April each year.

questions.question: Which of the following do you need to do in order to get a full driving licence?
questions.explanation: To get a full UK driving licence, you must pass a driving test, which tests both your knowledge and your practical skills.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: County Courts deal with criminal cases.
County Courts deal with civil disputes.
questions.explanation: County Courts deal with a wide range of civil disputes. These include people trying to get back money that is owed to them, cases involving personal injury, family matters, breaches of contract, and divorce.

questions.question: Which season of orchestral classical music has been organised by the BBC since 1927?
questions.explanation: The Proms is an eight-week summer season of orchestral classical music that takes place in various venues, including the Royal Albert Hall in London. It has been organised by the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) since 1927.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Hadrian's Wall was built by the Roman Emperor Hadrian.
Hadrian's Wall was built by the Picts (ancestors of the Scottish people) to keep out the Romans.
questions.explanation: The Emperor Hadrian built a wall in the north of England (Hadrian's Wall) to keep out the Picts (ancestors of the Scottish people).

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The Scottish Parliament can pass laws for Scotland on all matters.
questions.explanation: The Scottish Parliament can pass laws for Scotland on all matters that are not specifically reserved to the UK Parliament.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
'In 1921 a peace treaty was signed which led to Ireland becoming two countries.'
questions.explanation: In 1921 a peace treaty was signed and in 1922 Ireland became two countries. The six counties in the north which were mainly Protestant remained part of the UK under the name Northern Ireland. The rest of Ireland became the Irish Free State. It had its own government and became a republic in 1949.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: By 1400 the preferred language of the English court was French.
By 1400 the preferred language of the English court was English.
questions.explanation: By 1400 the preferred language of the royal court was English, which was also the language of official documents.

questions.question: After the Bill of Rights was passed in 1689, which TWO main political groups emerged?
questions.explanation: From 1689 onwards there were two main groups in Parliament, known as the Whigs and the Tories.

questions.question: Which TWO were 20th-century British discoveries or inventions?
choices: Cloning a mammal and mobile phones
questions.explanation: In 1996 Sir Ian Wilmut and Keith Campbell led a team which was the first to succeed in cloning a mammal. In the 1960s James Goodfellow invented the cashpoint (ATM).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Elizabeth I was not successful in balancing her wishes and views against those of the House of Lords and the House of Commons
Elizabeth I was successful in balancing her wishes and views against those of the House of Lords and the House of Commons
questions.explanation: Elizabeth was successful in balancing her wishes and views against those of the House of Lords and the House of Commons. Her successor James I and his son Charles I were less politically skilled.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: By the middle of the 17th century the last Welsh rebellions had been defeated.
By the middle of the 15th century the last Welsh rebellions had been defeated.
questions.explanation: The last Welsh rebellions were defeated by the middle of the 15th century.

questions.question: How many people serve on a jury in Scotland?
questions.explanation: In Scotland a jury has 15 members. In England, Wales and Northern Ireland a jury has 12 members.

questions.question: Which TWO are associated with Sir Francis Drake?
choices: Defeating the Spanish Armada and early flight
Defeating the Spanish Armada and sailing around the world
The Titanic and sailing around the world
questions.explanation:
Sir Francis Drake was one of the commanders in the defeat of the Spanish Armada. His ship, the Golden Hind, was one
of the first to sail right around (‘circumnavigate’) the world.

questions.question: What is the name of the UK currency?
questions.explanation: The currency in the UK is the pound sterling (symbol £). There are 100 pence in a pound.

questions.question: Which country did Germany invade in 1939 that led to the UK declaring war on Germany?
questions.explanation: When Adolf Hitler invaded Poland in 1939, Britain and France, declared war on Germany in order to stop his aggression.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The Battle of Agincourt is commemorated in the Bayeux Tapestry.
The Battle of Hastings is commemorated in the Bayeux Tapestry.
questions.explanation: The Bayeux Tapestry commemorates the victory of William, Duke of Normandy at the Battle of Hastings in 1066.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are recent British film actors that have won Oscars?
choices: Colin Firth and Robert Louis Stevenson
questions.explanation: Recent British actors to have won Oscars include Colin Firth, Sir Antony Hopkins, Dame Judi Dench, Kate Winslet and Tilda Swinton.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The Home Secretary is the government minister responsible for managing relationships with foreign countries.
questions.explanation: The Home Secretary is the government minister responsible for crime, policing and immigration. The Foreign Secretary is the government minister responsible for managing relationships with foreign countries.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
A husband who forces his wife to have sex can be charged with rape.
questions.explanation: Any man who forces a woman to have sex, including a woman's husband, can be charged with rape.

questions.question: What were TWO important aspects of the Reform Act of 1832?
choices: It abolished rotten boroughs and gave women the vote
It decreased the power of the monarch and it gave women the vote
It greatly increased the number of people who could vote and abolished rotten boroughs
It increased the power of the monarch and it gave women the vote
questions.explanation:
The Reform Act of 1832 greatly increased the number of people with the right to vote. The Act also abolished the old pocket and rotten
boroughs  (parliamentary seats where there were few voters) and more parliamentary seats were given to the towns and cities.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Members of the armed forces cannot stand for public office.
questions.explanation: Most citizens of the UK, Ireland or the Commonwealth aged 18 or over can stand for public office. There are some exceptions, including members of the armed forces.

questions.question: Who has to pay National Insurance Contributions?
choices: Almost everybody in the UK who is in paid work
Only single people with no dependants
questions.explanation: Almost everybody in the UK who is in paid work, including self-employed people, must pay National Insurance Contributions. The money raised is used to pay for state benefits and services such as the state retirement pension and the National Health Service (NHS).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The Mousetrap is a play that has been running in London's West End since 1952.
