The Mousetrap is an environmental policy aiming to prevent mice from destroying crops.
questions.explanation: The Mousetrap, a murder-mystery play by Dame Agatha Christie, has been running in the West End since 1952.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: When buying a car, you must pay an annual vehicle tax.
When buying a car, you do not need to pay vehicle tax if the previous owner has already paid it.
questions.explanation: When you buy a car, you must pay an annual vehicle tax, which cannot be passed on when a vehicle changes hands.

questions.question: What important event happened in England in 1066?
choices: The building of the Offa Dyke
questions.explanation: In 1066, William, the Duke of Normandy (in what is now northern France), defeated Harold, the Saxon king of England, at the Battle of Hastings. The Norman Conquest was the last successful foreign invasion of England and led to many changes in government and social structures in England.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following plants are particularly associated with the UK?
questions.explanation:
The countries that make up the UK
all have flowers which are particularly associated with them and which are sometimes worn on national saints’ days. In England, the flower is the rose; in Northern Ireland it is the shamrock.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
In 1805, at the Battle of Trafalgar, Admiral Nelson defeated the German fleet.
questions.explanation: Britain’s navy fought against combined French and Spanish fleets, winning the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805. Admiral Nelson was in charge of the British fleet at Trafalgar and was killed in the battle.

questions.question: What celebration takes place each year on 14 February?
questions.explanation:
Valentine’s Day, on 14 February, is when lovers exchange cards and
gifts. Sometimes people send anonymous cards to someone they
secretly admire.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Sir Steve Redgrave is a famous rower who won gold medals in five consecutive Olympic Games.
Sir Steve Redgrave is a famous film actor who has won several BAFTAs.
questions.explanation:
Sir Steve Redgrave won gold medals in rowing in five consecutive Olympic Games and is one of Britain’s greatest
Olympians.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
UK citizens must practise a Christian religion.
questions.explanation: False - everyone has the legal right to choose their religion, or to choose not to practise a religion.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
A traditional food in Wales is Ulster fry.
questions.explanation: Ulster fry is a traditional food in Northern Ireland. It is a fried meal with bacon, eggs, sausage, black pudding, white pudding, tomatoes, mushrooms, soda bread and potato bread.

questions.question: Why is Sir Edwin Lutyens famous?
choices: He won a gold medal at the London 2012 Olympic Games.
He was the first UK Prime Minister.
He invented the World Wide Web.
questions.explanation: Sir Edwin Lutyens was a famous 20th-century architect who designed the Cenotaph in Whitehall.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Florence Nightingale is famous for her work on education in the 19th century.
questions.explanation:
Florence Nightingale (1820–1910) worked in military hospitals, treating soldiers
who were fighting in the Crimean War. She and her fellow nurses improved the conditions in the hospital and reduced the mortality rate. She is often regarded as the founder of modern nursing.

questions.question: What happens when a Member of Parliament (MP) dies or resigns?
choices: The post remains vacant until the next General Election.
Their party chooses someone to fill the post until the next General Election.
A by-election is held to replace the MP.
A neighbouring MP looks after the constituency.
questions.explanation: If an MP dies or resigns, there will be a fresh election, called a by-election, in his or her constituency.

questions.question: During which part of the year are pantomime productions staged in theatres?
questions.explanation: Many theatres produce a pantomime at Christmas time. They are light-hearted plays with music and comedy, enjoyed by family audiences.

questions.question: How often are Members of Parliament (MPs) elected?
questions.explanation: MPs are elected at a General Election, which is held at least every five years.

questions.question: Which of the following is dealt with under civil law?
questions.explanation: Debt is covered by civil law. People might be taken to court if they owe money to someone.

questions.question: Which TWO religions celebrate Diwali?
questions.explanation: Diwali is celebrated by Hindus and Sikhs. It celebrates the victory of good over evil and the gaining of knowledge.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are famous British film directors?
choices: Sir Alfred Hitchcock and Evelyn Waugh
Sir Alfred Hitchcock and Sir Ridley Scott
Evelyn Waugh and Sir Ridley Scott
questions.explanation: Sir Alfred Hitchcock and Sir Ridley Scott are British film directors who have had great success in the UK and internationally.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
During the Victorian period the British Empire became the largest empire the world has ever seen.
questions.explanation:
During the Victorian period, the British Empire grew to cover all
of India, Australia and large parts of Africa. It became the largest
empire the world has ever seen, with an estimated population of
more than 400 million people

questions.question: Which TWO points about slavery are correct?
choices: William Wilberforce was a leading abolitionist and the Royal Navy refused to stop ships carrying slaves
Quakers set up the first anti-slavery groups and the Royal Navy refused to stop ships carrying slaves
Slavery survived in the British Empire until the early 20th century and the Royal Navy refused to stop ships carrying slaves
William Wilberforce was a leading abolitionist and Quakers set up the first anti-slavery groups
questions.explanation:
The first formal anti-slavery groups were set up by the Quakers in
the late 1700s, and they petitioned Parliament to ban the practice.
William Wilberforce, an evangelical Christian and a member of Parliament, also played an important part in changing the law, and in 1833 the Emancipation Act abolished slavery throughout the British Empire.

questions.question: What is the minimum age at which you can legally buy alcohol in the UK?
questions.explanation: It is a criminal offence to sell alcohol to anyone who is under 18 or to buy alcohol for people who are under the age of 18. (There is one exception: people aged 16 or over can drink alcohol with a meal in a hotel or restaurant).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The 'Swinging Sixties' was a period of religious change.
The 'Swinging Sixties' was a period of social change.
questions.explanation: The 1960s was a period of significant social change. It was known as ‘the Swinging Sixties’. There was growth in British fashion, cinema and popular music.

questions.question: Which event occurs each year on the third Sunday in June?
questions.explanation:
Father’s Day is the third Sunday in June. Children send cards or buy
gifts for their fathers.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The Scottish Parliament sits in Edinburgh.
questions.explanation:
The Scottish Parliament was formed in 1999. It sits in Edinburgh, the
capital city of Scotland.

questions.question: What must police officers do?
questions.explanation: Police officers must obey the law. They must not be rude or abusive, make a false statement, misuse their authority, or commit racial discrimination.

questions.question: How are local councils funded?
choices: Through money raised from local fundraising events
By central government and local taxes
questions.explanation: Towns, cities and rural areas in the UK are governed by democratically elected councils, often called 'local authorities'. These are funded by money from central government and by local taxes.

questions.question: What is the minimum age you can drive a car or motor cycle in the UK?
questions.explanation: In the UK, you must be at least 17 years old to drive a car or motor cycle and you must have a driving licence to drive on public roads.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are British overseas territories?
questions.explanation: There are several British overseas territories in other parts of the world, such as St Helena and the Falkland Islands. They are linked to the UK but are not a part of it.

questions.question: Which sport can be traced back to 15th-century Scotland?
questions.explanation:
The modern game of golf can be traced back to 15th century
Scotland.

questions.question: To which TWO international associations or agreements does the UK belong?
choices: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA)
The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and the Commonwealth
The Commonwealth and the Arab League
The Commonwealth and the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA)
questions.explanation: The UK belongs to many International bodies including NATO (North Atlantic Treaty Organization) and the Commonwealth.

questions.question: The term 'D-Day' refers to which event in British history?
choices: Landing of allied troops in Normandy
Dropping of the atom bomb on Japan
End of the war in Europe in 1945
questions.explanation:
On 6 June 1944 (often referred to as 'D-Day'), allied forces landed in Normandy. Following victory on the beaches of Normandy, the allied forces pressed on through France
and eventually into Germany.

questions.question: If your car is more than three years old, how often will it need a Ministry of Transport (MOT) test?
questions.explanation: If your car is over three years old, you must take it for a Ministry of Transport (MOT) test every year. It is an offence not to have an MOT certificate if your vehicle is more than three years old.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The 'Swinging Sixties' is a reference to the 1860s.
questions.explanation:
The decade of the 1960s was a period of significant social change.
It was known as ‘the Swinging Sixties’. There was growth in British
fashion, cinema and popular music.

questions.question:
Is the following statement TRUE or FALSE?
British values and principles are based on history and traditions.
questions.explanation: British society is founded on fundamental values and principles, which are based on history and traditions and are protected by law, customs and expectations.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Pantomimes are plays based on fairy stories.
questions.explanation: Pantomime plays are a British tradition. Many theatres produce a pantomime at Christmas time. They are based on fairy stories and are light-hearted plays with music and comedy.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The main political parties actively look for members of the public to help at elections and contribute to their costs.
questions.explanation:
The main political parties actively look for members of the public
to join their debates, contribute to their costs, and help at elections
for Parliament or for local government. They have branches in most constituencies and hold policy-making conferences every year.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The Black Death caused the death of one third of people in Ireland
The Black Death caused the death of one third of people in England, Scotland and Wales
questions.explanation:
In 1348, a disease, probably a form of plague, came to Britain.
This was known as the Black Death. One third of the population of
England died and a similar proportion in Scotland and Wales.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Wales united with England during the reign of Henry VIII.
questions.explanation: During the reign of Henry VIII, Wales became formally united with England by the Act for the Government of Wales

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The public can listen to debates in the House of Commons.
No member of the public is allowed to attend debates in the House of Commons.
questions.explanation: The public can listen to debates from public galleries in both the House of Commons and the House of Lords.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Rugby was introduced to ancient Britain by Viking invaders.
Rugby originated in England in the early 19th century.
questions.explanation: Rugby originated in England in the early 19th century and is a very popular sport in the UK today.

questions.question: Which cross on the Union Flag represents the patron saint of Ireland?
questions.explanation: The cross of St Patrick, patron saint of Ireland, is a diagonal red cross on a white background.

questions.question: Which of these was Isambard Kingdom Brunel famous for building?
questions.explanation: Isambard Kingdom Brunel was a famous Victorian engineer who built railway lines, bridges, tunnels and ships.

questions.question: Which TWO records tell us about England during the time of William the Conqueror?
choices: The Domesday Book and the Bayeux Tapestry
The Diary of Samuel Pepys and the Bayeux Tapestry
The Domesday Book and the Magna Carta
The Diary of Samuel Pepys and the Magna Carta
questions.explanation: The Domesday Book is a record of towns and villages in England. The Bayeux Tapestry tells the story of the Norman Conquest.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The Isle of Man is a Crown dependency.
questions.explanation: Like the Channel Islands, the Isle of Man is a Crown dependency with its own government.

questions.question: What was the name given to supporters of King Charles I during the Civil War?
questions.explanation: The king's supporters during the Civil War were called Cavaliers. Those who supported Parliament were called Roundheads.

questions.question: Which of the following UK landmarks is in Northern Ireland?
questions.explanation:
Located on the north-east coast of Northern Ireland, the Giant’s
Causeway is a land formation of columns made from volcanic
lava.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: You have to be aged 18 or over to buy a National Lottery ticket.
You have to be aged 16 or over to buy a National Lottery ticket.
questions.explanation: People under the age of 18 are not allowed to participate in the National Lottery.

questions.question: The Bill of Rights of 1689 limited whose powers?
questions.explanation: The Bill of Rights of 1689 confirmed the rights of Parliament and the limits of the king’s power.

questions.question: Which TWO fought in wars against Napoleon?
choices: Winston Churchill and the Duke of Wellington
Margaret Thatcher and the Duke of Wellington
Admiral Nelson and the Duke of Wellington
questions.explanation: Admiral Nelson commanded the British fleet at the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805. He died during the battle. The Duke of Wellington defeated Napoleon at the Battle of Waterloo in 1815.

questions.question: How often does Prime Minister's Questions occur when Parliament is sitting?
questions.explanation: Prime Minister's Questions takes place every week while Parliament is sitting.

questions.question: St Andrew is the patron saint of which country?
questions.explanation: St Andrew is the patron saint of Scotland, and is celebrated on 30 November each year.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Pressure and lobby groups try to influence government policy.
questions.explanation: Pressure and lobby groups are organisations which try to influence government policy. They play an important role in politics.

questions.question: How can you reduce your carbon footprint?
choices: Buy duty-free products when you're abroad
questions.explanation:
A good way to support your local community is to shop for products
locally where you can. This will help businesses and farmers in your area and in Britain. It will also reduce your carbon footprint, because the products you buy will not have had to travel as far.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Every household with a device that can be used to watch TV must have a television licence.
People who watch TV only on their computers do not need to pay for a television licence.
questions.explanation: Everyone in the UK with a TV, computer or other medium which can be used for watching TV must have a television licence. One licence covers all of the equipment in one home, except when people rent different rooms in a shared house and each has a separate tenancy agreement – those people must each buy a separate licence.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are part of the UK government?
choices: The cabinet and the civil service
The cabinet and the National Trust
questions.explanation: There are several different parts of government in the UK, including the cabinet and the civil service.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The UK offers its citizens and permanent residents freedom of speech.
The UK does not allow citizens or permanent residents to voice opinions publicly.
questions.explanation: The UK offers citizens and permanent residents various freedoms and rights, including freedom of speech.

questions.question: How is the Speaker of the House of Commons chosen?
questions.explanation: The Speaker is chosen by other Members of Parliament (MPs) in a secret ballot. The Speaker keeps order during political debates to make sure the rules are followed.

questions.question: Who was given the title of Lord Protector in the 17th century?
questions.explanation: Oliver Cromwell was given the title of Lord Protector and ruled until his death in 1658.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Sir Mo Farah and Dame Jessica Ennis-Hill are well-known athletes who won
gold medals at the 2012 London Olympics.
questions.explanation: Sir Mo Farah won gold medals in the 5,000 and 10,000 metres, and Dame Jessica Ennis-Hill won a gold medal in the heptathlon.

questions.question: Which TWO political parties formed the coalition government in 2010?
questions.explanation: In May 2010, the Conservative and Liberal Democrat parties formed a coalition and the leader of the Conservative Party, David Cameron, became Prime Minister.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) is financed by income tax.
questions.explanation:
The money from TV licences is used to pay for the British
Broadcasting Corporation (BBC). Everyone in the UK with a TV, computer or other medium which can be used for watching TV must have a television licence.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The 40 days before Easter are known as Lent.
questions.explanation: Lent is a time when Christians take time to reflect and prepare for Easter. Traditionally, people would fast during this period and today many people will give something up, like a favourite food.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The capital city of Scotland is Edinburgh.
The capital city of Scotland is Glasgow.
questions.explanation: The capital city of Scotland is Edinburgh.

questions.question: When is a by-election for a parliamentary seat held?
choices: When a Member of Parliament (MP) dies or resigns
When the Prime Minister decides to call one
questions.explanation: If an MP dies or resigns, there will be a fresh election, called a by-election, in his or her constituency.

questions.question: What sort of cases do Crown Courts and Sheriff Courts deal with?
questions.explanation: In England, Wales and Northern Ireland, serious offences are tried in front of a judge and jury in a Crown Court. In Scotland, serious cases are heard in a Sheriff Court with either a sheriff or a sheriff with a jury.

questions.question: Bobby Moore is famous for his achievements in which sport?
questions.explanation: Bobby Moore captained the England football team that won the World Cup in 1966.

questions.question: How old do you have to be to go into a betting shop in the UK?
questions.explanation: In the UK, people often enjoy a gamble on sports or other events. You have to be over 18 to go into betting shops or gambling clubs.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Most people live in the countryside in the UK.
questions.explanation: Most people in the UK live in towns and cities, but much of Britain is still countryside.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Shakespeare wrote 'To be or not to be'.
Shakespeare wrote 'We will fight on the beaches'.
questions.explanation: 'To be or not to be' is a quotation from Hamlet, written by William Shakespeare.

questions.question: What is a fundamental principle of British life?
questions.explanation: British society is founded on fundamental values and principles which all those living in the UK should respect and support. One of these principles is democracy.

questions.question: Which TWO actions can a judge take if a public body is not respecting someone's legal rights?
choices: Order the body to pay compensation and close down the public body
Place the body's members in prison and close down the public body
Order the body to change its practices and order the body to pay compensation
Place the body's members in prison and order the body to change its practices
questions.explanation: If judges find that a public body is not respecting someone's legal rights, they can order that body to change its practices and/or pay compensation.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are UK landmarks?
choices: Edinburgh Castle and the London Eye
The Eisteddfodd and the National Trust
The National Trust and the London Eye
The National Trust and Edinburgh Castle
questions.explanation: Edinburgh Castle is a dominant feature of the skyline in Edinburgh, Scotland. The London Eye is situated on the southern bank of the River Thames. Both are UK landmarks.

questions.question: Which is the UK's most popular sport?
questions.explanation: Football is the UK's most popular sport. It has a long history in the UK, and the English Premier League attracts a huge international audience.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: It is free to visit the Houses of Parliament to listen to debates.
It costs £15 per person to visit the Houses of Parliament to listen to debates.
questions.explanation:
The public can listen to debates from public galleries in both the House of Commons and the
House of Lords. Entrance is free. You can write to your local MP in advance to ask for tickets or you can queue on the day at the public entrance.

questions.question: Where is the UK parliament based?
questions.explanation: The UK is governed by the parliament sitting in Westminster.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Several British writers have won the Nobel Prize in Literature.
No British writer has won the Nobel Prize in Literature.
questions.explanation: Several British writers, including the novelist Sir William Golding, the poet Seamus Heaney, and the playwright Harold Pinter, have won the Nobel Prize in Literature.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Britain and Germany developed Concorde, a supersonic passenger aircraft.
questions.explanation: False - Britain and France developed Concorde, the supersonic passenger aircraft. It first flew in 1969 and began carrying passengers in 1976. Concorde was retired from service in 2003.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
There is no place in British society for extremism or intolerance.
questions.explanation: British society is founded on fundamental values and principles which all those living in the UK respect and support. There is no place for extremism or intolerance.

questions.question: In which country was the composer George Frederick Handel born?
questions.explanation: George Frederick Handel was born in Germany in 1685. He spent many years in the UK and became a British citizen in 1727.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
'Great Britain' refers only to England, Scotland and Wales.
questions.explanation: Great Britain' refers only to England, Scotland and Wales, not to Northern Ireland.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
An example of a civil law case is when you have purchased a faulty item and made a legal complaint.
questions.explanation: Civil law is used to settle disputes between individuals or groups.

questions.question: Which of the following is a responsibility you will have as a citizen or permanent resident of the UK?
choices: To keep your dog on a lead at all times
To avoid shopping on a Sunday
To look after yourself and your family
questions.explanation: There are responsibilities and freedoms which are shared by all those living in the UK. These include looking after yourself and your family.

questions.question: Which TWO foods are associated with England?
choices: Roast beef, and fish and chips
questions.explanation: Roast beef is served with potatoes, vegetables, Yorkshire puddings and other accompaniments. Fish and chips are also popular in England.

questions.question: Which TWO developments are associated with the 'Swinging Sixties'?
choices: Reform of abortion law and introduction of decimal currency
Reform of children's rights law and introduction of decimal currency
Reform of children's rights law and reform of divorce law
Reform of abortion law and reform of divorce law
questions.explanation: During the 1960s (a period known as the 'Swinging Sixties'), a number of social changes took place. Many social laws were liberalised, for example, in regard to abortion and divorce in England, Wales and Scotland.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Gilbert and Sullivan were a comedy double act.
Gilbert and Sullivan wrote many comic operas.
questions.explanation:
In the 19th century, Gilbert and Sullivan wrote comic operas, often
making fun of popular culture and politics. These operas include
HMS Pinafore, The Pirates of Penzance and The Mikado.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following were introduced in the early 20th century?
choices: Child Benefit payments and free school meals
The National Health Service (NHS) and Child Benefit payments
The National Health Service (NHS) and old-age pensions
Old-age pensions and free school meals
questions.explanation: The early 20th century was a time of social progress. Old-age pensions and free school meals were just a few of the important measures introduced.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have parliaments or assemblies of their own.
Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland do not have parliaments or assemblies of their own.
questions.explanation: Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have parliaments or assemblies of their own, with devolved powers in defined areas.

questions.question: What type of church is the Church of Scotland?
questions.explanation:
In Scotland, the national Church is the Church of Scotland, which is
a Presbyterian Church.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Women in Britain make up about a quarter of the workforce.
Women in Britain make up about half of the workforce.
questions.explanation: Women in Britain make up about half of the workforce. Employment opportunities for women are much greater than they were in the past.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland each have devolved administrations which give them total control over all policies and laws.
questions.explanation: Some powers have been devolved from central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them. Some policy and laws remain under central UK government control.

questions.question: St David is the patron saint of which country of the UK?
questions.explanation: St David is the patron saint of Wales, and St David's Day is celebrated on 1 March each year.

questions.question: What is a bank holiday?
choices: A public holiday when banks and many other businesses close for the day
A holiday just for people working in banks
A week off for everyone in the UK
An extra holiday entitlement for working longer hours than usual
questions.explanation: There are public holidays each year, called bank holidays, when banks and many other businesses close for the day.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
In the UK you are expected to treat others with fairness.
questions.explanation: There are responsibilities and freedoms which are shared by all those living in the UK.  These include treating others with fairness.

questions.question: Which of the following is a British overseas territory?
questions.explanation: There are several British overseas territories in other parts of the world, such as the Falkland Islands.

questions.question: Which of these events changed the powers of the king in 1215?
questions.explanation: In 1215, King John was forced by his noblemen to agree to a number of demands. The result was a charter of rights called the Magna Carta (which means the Great Charter). The Magna Carta established the idea that even the king was subject to the law. It protected the rights of the nobility and restricted the king’s power to collect taxes or to make or change laws.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The National Trust is a charity that works to preserve important buildings in the UK.
The National Trust is a government-run organisation that provides funding for charities.
questions.explanation: The National Trust in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, and the National Trust for Scotland, work to preserve important buildings, coastline and countryside.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
You can support your local community by becoming a school governor.
questions.explanation: School governors are people from the local community who wish to make a positive contribution to children’s education.

questions.question: What is the youngest age at which you can be asked to serve on a jury?
questions.explanation: Anyone who is on the electoral register and is aged 18–70 (18–75 in England and Wales) can be asked to serve on a jury.

questions.question: Where do the Laurence Olivier awards take place?
questions.explanation:
The Laurence Olivier Awards take place annually at different venues
in London. There are a variety of categories, including best director,
best actor and best actress.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The Highland Clearances took place in Scotland.
The Highland Clearances took place in Ireland.
questions.explanation: The Highland Clearances took place in Scotland. Many Scottish landlords destroyed individual small farms (known as ‘crofts’) to make space for large flocks of sheep and cattle.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Members of the House of Lords are not elected by the people.
Members of the House of Lords are voted in by members of the House of Commons.
questions.explanation: Members of the House of Lords are not elected by the people and do not represent a constituency.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The UK is a member of NATO.
The UK has never been a member of NATO.
questions.explanation: The UK is a member of NATO (North Atlantic Treaty Organization). NATO is a group of European and North American countries that have agreed to help each other if they come under attack. It also aims to maintain peace between all of its members.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Police and Crime Commissioners (PCCs) are appointed through a public election.
Police and Crime Commissioners (PCCs) are appointed by the local council.
questions.explanation: The public in England and Wales elect Police and Crime Commissioners (PCCs). The first elections for PCCs were held in November 2012.

questions.question: With which sport do you associate Lewis Hamilton, Jenson Button and Damon Hill?
questions.explanation: Lewis Hamilton, Jenson Button and Damon Hill are all British Grand Prix drivers who have won the Formula 1 World Championship.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: There are a few Members of Parliament who do not represent any of the main political parties.
All Members of Parliament have to belong to a political party.
questions.explanation: There are a few Members of Parliament (MPs) who do not represent any of the main political parties. They are called 'independents'.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The capital cities of the nations of the UK are London, Swansea, Glasgow and Dublin.
The capital cities of the nations of the UK are London, Cardiff, Edinburgh and Belfast.
questions.explanation: The capital cities of the nations of the UK are: London (England), Cardiff (Wales), Edinburgh (Scotland) and Belfast (Northern Ireland).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The UK is made up of England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland.
The UK is made up of England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.
questions.explanation:
The UK is made up of England, Scotland, Wales and Northern
Ireland. The rest of Ireland is an independent country.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The Channel Islands are a part of the UK.
questions.explanation: The Channel Islands are closely linked with the UK but are not part of it. They have their own governments and are called ‘Crown dependencies’.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: After the Bill of Rights was declared in 1689, two political groups emerged, the Whigs and the Tories.
After the Bill of Rights was declared in 1689, two political groups emerged, the Labour Party and the Greens.
questions.explanation:
After the Bill of Rights was declared in 1689,  there were two main groups in Parliament, known
as the Whigs and the Tories. (The modern Conservative Party is
still sometimes referred to as the Tories.)

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
William Blake, Lord Byron and Robert Browning were all famous golfers.
questions.explanation: William Blake, Lord Byron and Robert Browning were all poets.

questions.question: Which of these groups can take part in the National Citizen Service programme?
choices: All children up to the age of 17
questions.explanation: The National Citizen Service programme gives 16- and 17-year-olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills and take part in a community project.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Northern Ireland and Scotland have their own banknotes.
questions.explanation: Northern Ireland and Scotland have their own banknotes, which are valid everywhere in the UK.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Lancelot 'Capability' Brown and Gertrude Jekyll were famous garden designers.
Lancelot 'Capability' Brown and Gertrude Jekyll were famous characters in a Sherlock Holmes story.
questions.explanation: In the 18th century, Lancelot ‘Capability’ Brown designed the grounds around country houses so that the landscape appeared to be natural, with grass, trees and lakes. Later, Gertrude Jekyll often worked with Sir Edwin Lutyens to design colourful gardens around the houses he designed.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The first person to use the title Prime Minister was Sir Robert Walpole.
The first person to use the title Prime Minister was Sir Christopher Wren.
questions.explanation: Sir Robert Walpole was the first person to be called Prime Minister. He was Prime Minister from 1721 until 1742.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are part of the UK?
questions.explanation:
The UK is made up of England, Scotland, Wales and Northern
Ireland.

questions.question: The term 'suffragettes' is associated with which group of people?
questions.explanation:
In the late 19th and early
20th centuries, an increasing number of women campaigned and
demonstrated for greater rights and, in particular, the right to vote.
They formed the women’s suffrage movement and became known
as ‘suffragettes’.

questions.question: In 1999, what happened to hereditary peers in the House of Lords?
choices: Women were allowed to inherit their titles.
They lost their automatic right to attend the House of Lords.
questions.explanation: Since 1999, hereditary peers have lost the automatic right to attend the House of Lords. They now elect a few of their number to represent them in the House of Lords.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Cricket matches can last up to five days.
Cricket matches can last up to two weeks.
questions.explanation: Some cricket games can last for up to five days and still result in a draw.

questions.question: Which TWO are Protestant Christian groups in the UK?
questions.explanation: Baptists and Methodists are Protestant Christian groups. Other Protestant groups in the UK include the Church of England, the Church of Scotland, Presbyterians and Quakers.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following were major welfare changes introduced from 1945 to 1950?
choices: The National Health Service (NHS) and a national system of benefits
The State retirement pension and employment exchanges
The National Health Service (NHS) and employment exchanges
Employment exchanges and free school meals
questions.explanation: The Labour government that was elected in 1945 established the National Health Service (NHS) and a national system of benefits.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Winston Churchill was the British Prime Minister during the First World War.
Winston Churchill was the British Prime Minister during the Second World War.
questions.explanation: Winston Churchill was the British Prime Minister from 1940  to 1945, during the Second World War.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are part of the UK?
questions.explanation:
The UK is made up of England, Scotland, Wales and Northern
Ireland. The rest of Ireland is an independent country.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
On the 1st of April, people in the UK play jokes on each other until midday.
questions.explanation:
April Fool’s Day, 1 April, is a day when people play jokes on each
other until midday. The television and newspapers often have stories that are April Fool jokes.

questions.question: What is the title of the National Anthem of the UK?
questions.explanation: The National Anthem of the UK is 'God Save the King'. It is played at important national occasions and at events attended by the King or the Royal Family.

questions.question: Which of the following is a fundamental principle of British life?
questions.explanation: Individual liberty is a fundamental principle of British life. There is no place in British society for extremism or intolerance.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The Wars of the Roses were between the Houses of Lancaster and York.
The Wars of the Roses were between the Houses of Windsor and Tudor.
questions.explanation:
In 1455, a civil war was begun to decide who should be king of
England. It was fought between the supporters of two families:
the House of Lancaster and the House of York. This war was called
the Wars of the Roses, because the symbol of Lancaster was a red
rose and the symbol of York was a white rose.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The daffodil is the national flower of Wales.
questions.explanation: The daffodil is the national flower of Wales, and is worn on St David's Day.

questions.question: Which parts of the United Kingdom have devolved governments?
questions.explanation: Some powers have been devolved from central government to give people in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland more control over matters that directly affect them.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
In the UK you are expected to respect the rights of others to have their own opinions.
questions.explanation: There are responsibilities and freedoms which are shared by all those living in the UK. These include respecting the rights of others, including their right to their own opinions.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The House of Lords always acts as the government wishes.
questions.explanation: The House of Lords is normally more independent of the government than the House of Commons.

questions.question: Which of the following groups of adults is NOT eligible to vote in all UK elections?
choices: Citizens of the Commonwealth who are resident in the UK
Citizens of Ireland who are resident in the UK
questions.explanation: Adult citizens of the UK, and citizens of the Commonwealth and Ireland who are resident in the UK, can vote in all public elections.

questions.question: Which TWO are famous gardens in the UK?
questions.explanation: Sissinghurst is in England and Bodnant Garden is in Wales.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
On average, boys in the UK leave school with better qualifications than girls.
questions.explanation: On average, girls leave school with better qualifications than boys. Also, more women than men study at university.

questions.question: What type of government was formed after the General Election of 2010?
questions.explanation: The 2010 coalition was formed by the Conservative and Liberal Democrat parties.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Carrying a weapon is an example of a criminal offence.
Being in debt is an example of a criminal offence.
questions.explanation: Carrying a weapon is one example of a criminal offence. Crimes are usually investigated by the police and punished by the courts.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
When Queen Anne died in 1714, parliament chose a German to be the next king of England.
questions.explanation:
Queen Anne had no surviving children, so Parliament chose a German, George I, to be the next king, because he was Anne’s nearest
Protestant relative.

questions.question: Which TWO are famous British composers?
choices: Henry Purcell and Ralph Vaughan Williams
Johann Sebastian Bach and Henry Purcell
Claude Debussy and Johann Sebastian Bach
questions.explanation: Henry Purcell wrote church music, opera and other pieces, and developed a British style distinct from that elsewhere in Europe. Ralph Vaughan Williams wrote music for orchestras and choirs. He was strongly influenced by traditional English folk music.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Sir Andy Murray is the first British man to sail around the world.
Sir Andy Murray is the first British man to win a singles tennis title in a Grand Slam tournament since 1936.
questions.explanation: Sir Andy Murray is a Scottish tennis player and the first British man to win a singles tennis title in a Grand Slam tournament since 1936.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE OR FALSE? 
Members of the public are allowed to attend Youth Court hearings.
questions.explanation: Members of the public are not allowed in Youth Courts, and the name or photographs of the accused young person cannot be published in newspapers or used by the media.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The small claims procedure is an informal way of helping people to settle minor disputes.
The small claims procedure helps people to make small home insurance claims.
questions.explanation: The small claims procedure is an informal way of helping people to settle minor disputes without spending a lot of time and money using a lawyer.

questions.question: How old do you need to be in order to stand for public office?
questions.explanation: Most citizens of the UK, Ireland or the Commonwealth aged 18 or over can stand for public office.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This period is often called 'the Enlightenment'.
questions.explanation:
During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed. This period is often called ‘the Enlightenment’. One of the most important principles of the Enlightenment was that
everyone should have the right to their own political and religious beliefs and that the state should not try to dictate to them.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following were famous Victorians?
choices: Isambard Kingdom Brunel and Margaret Thatcher
Isambard Kingdom Brunel and Florence Nightingale
questions.explanation: Isambard Kingdom Brunel (1806–1859) was a famous engineer, and Florence Nightingale (1820–1910) established a training school for nurses, the first of its kind.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following were English Civil War battles?
questions.explanation: The Battles of Marston Moor and Naseby were English Civil War battles.

questions.question: What is a fundamental principle of British life?
choices: The rule of the upper classes
The rule of your local Member of Parliament (MP)
questions.explanation: The rule of law is a fundamental principle of British life. British society is founded on fundamental values and principles which all those living in the UK should respect and support.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Dundee and Aberdeen are cities in Northern Ireland.
questions.explanation: Dundee and Aberdeen are cities in Scotland.

questions.question: Which cross on the Union Flag represents the patron saint of Scotland?
questions.explanation: The cross of St Andrew, patron saint of Scotland, is a diagonal white cross on a blue ground.

questions.question: What are TWO benefits of volunteering?
choices: You can earn additional money and you are given a courtesy car as transport
You can meet new people and you are given a courtesy car as transport
You can meet new people and you help to make your community a better place
You can earn additional money and you can meet new people
questions.explanation: Volunteering is working for good causes without payment. There are many benefits to volunteering, including meeting new people and helping make your community a better place.

questions.question: Hadrian's Wall was built to keep out whom?
questions.explanation: The Roman Emperor Hadrian built the wall in the north of England to keep out the Picts (ancestors of the Scottish people).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Volunteering is a good way to earn additional money.
Volunteering is a way of helping others without receiving payment.
questions.explanation: Volunteering is working for good causes without payment. There are many activities you can do as a volunteer, such as working with the homeless and helping improve the environment.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
John Constable (1776–1837) founded the modern police force in England.
questions.explanation: John Constable was a landscape painter most famous for his works of Dedham Vale on the Suffolk–Essex border in the east of England.

questions.question: Which TWO developments were features of the Industrial Revolution?
choices: Changes in the law and steam power
Medical advances and changes in the law
questions.explanation: Britain was the first country to industrialise on a large scale. This happened because of the development of machinery and the use of steam power.

questions.question: Which TWO services are funded by National Insurance Contributions?
choices: State retirement pension and National Health Service (NHS)
Supermarket home deliveries and National Health Service (NHS)
Local taxi services and state retirement pension
State retirement pension and supermarket home deliveries
questions.explanation: Almost everybody in the UK who is in paid work, including self-employed people, must pay National Insurance Contributions. The money raised is used to pay for state benefits and services such as the state retirement pension and the National Health Service (NHS).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: George and Robert Stephenson were famous pioneers of railway engines.
George and Robert Stephenson were famous pioneers of agricultural changes.
questions.explanation: George and Robert Stephenson were famous pioneers of railway engines.

questions.question: Which part of the UK is associated with Robert Burns (1759–1796)?
questions.explanation: Robert Burns is associated with Scotland. He was a poet. One of his best-known works is the song Auld Lang Syne.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Donated blood is used by hospitals to help people with a wide range of injuries and illnesses
Donated blood is not used by hospitals to help people with a wide range of injuries and illnesses
questions.explanation:
Donated blood is used by hospitals to help people with a wide range
of injuries and illnesses. Giving blood only takes about an hour to do.

questions.question: To apply for UK citizenship or permanent residency, which TWO things do you need?
choices: An ability to speak and read English, and a good knowledge of life in the UK
A UK bank account and an ability to speak and read English
A UK bank account and a good understanding of life in the UK
An ability to speak and read English, and a driving licence
questions.explanation:
To apply to become a permanent resident or a naturalised citizen of
the UK, you must be able to speak and read English and have a good understanding of life in the UK.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: In 1588 the English defeated the Spanish Armada.
In 1588 the English defeated German bomber planes.
questions.explanation: In 1588, the English defeated the Spanish Armada (a large fleet of ships), which had been sent by Spain to conquer England and restore Catholicism.

questions.question: Which of the following is the capital city of the UK?
questions.explanation: The capital city of the UK is London, which is in England.

questions.question: Which of the following is a responsibility you will have as a citizen or permanent resident of the UK?
choices: Using your car as much as possible
Looking after the area in which you live and the environment
questions.explanation: There are responsibilities and freedoms which are shared by all those living in the UK.  These include looking after the area in which you live and the environment.

questions.question: What was the Reformation?
choices: A reduction in the power of the nobles
A movement against the authority of the Pope
A part of the Wars of the Roses
questions.explanation: The Reformation occurred across Europe. It was a movement against the authority of the Pope and the ideas and practices of the Roman Catholic Church.

questions.question: Which collection of poems was written by Geoffrey Chaucer?
questions.explanation:
Geoffrey Chaucer wrote a series
of poems about a group of people going to Canterbury
on a pilgrimage. This collection of poems is called The Canterbury
Tales.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following types of case are held in County Courts?
choices: Minor criminal offences and breaches of contract
questions.explanation: County Courts deal with a wide range of civil disputes, including divorce and other family matters, and breaches of contract.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following are major outdoor music festivals?
choices: Royal Ascot and the Isle of Wight Festival
Isle of Wight Festival and Glastonbury
questions.explanation: Festival season takes place across the UK every summer, with major events in various locations. Famous festivals include Glastonbury, the Isle of Wight Festival and Creamfields.

questions.question: For which TWO reasons is Henry VIII remembered?
choices: Married six times and fought in the Battle of Agincourt
Married six times and broke away from the Church of Rome
Introduced the game of croquet and married six times
Introduced the game of croquet and fought in the Battle of Agincourt
questions.explanation: Henry VIII is remembered for breaking away from the Catholic Church of Rome and marrying six times.

questions.question: Which countries make up 'Great Britain'?
questions.explanation: 'Great Britain' refers only to England, Scotland and Wales, not to Northern Ireland. The official name of the country is the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

questions.question: Which TWO of the following were important 20th-century inventors?
choices: Tim Berners-Lee and Isambard Kingdom Brunel
George Stephenson and Isambard Kingdom Brunel
questions.explanation: Alan Turing (1912–1954) invented a theoretical mathematical device called a Turing Machine that led to the development of the modern-day computer. Tim Berners-Lee (1955–) invented the World Wide Web.

questions.question: When a Member of Parliament (MP) dies or resigns, what is the election called that is held to replace them?
questions.explanation: If a Member of Parliament (MP) dies or resigns, there will be a fresh election, called a by-election, in his or her constituency.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: The Reform Act of 1832 reduced the number of people who had the right to vote.
The Reform Act of 1832 increased the number of people who had the right to vote.
questions.explanation:
The Reform Act of 1832 greatly increased the number of people with the right to vote. There was a permanent shift of political
power from the countryside to the towns but voting was still based
on ownership of property. This meant that members of the working class were still unable to vote.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
choices: Decisions on government policies are made by the monarch.
Decisions on government policies are made by the Prime Minister and cabinet.
questions.explanation: The monarch has regular meetings with the Prime Minister, and can advise, warn and encourage, but the decisions on government policies are made by the Prime Minister and cabinet.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The Lake District is England's largest national park.
questions.explanation: The Lake District is England’s largest national park. It covers 912 square miles (2,362 square kilometres).

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
A General Election occurs every eight years.
questions.explanation: A General Election is held at least every five years.

questions.question: When you arrive at a polling station, the staff will ask for which of the following:
choices: Life in the UK test certificate.
questions.explanation: People vote in elections at places called polling stations, or polling places in Scotland. When you arrive at the polling station, the staff will ask for your name, address and photo ID. You can check that you have the right photo ID at www.gov.uk/how-to-vote/photo-id-youll-need. You will then get your ballot paper, which you take to a polling booth to fill in privately.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
All citizens and permanent residents of the UK can choose which laws they follow.
questions.explanation: There are responsibilities and freedoms which are shared by all those living in the UK.  These include respecting and obeying the law.

questions.question: Which TWO famous London buildings are built in the 19th-century 'gothic' style?
choices: The Houses of Parliament and Buckingham Palace
St Paul's Cathedral and St Pancras Station
St Paul's Cathedral and Buckingham Palace
The Houses of Parliament and St Pancras Station
questions.explanation: In the 19th century, the medieval 'gothic' style became popular again. The Houses of Parliament and St Pancras Station were built at this time.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
Getting to know your neighbours can help you to become part of the community.
questions.explanation: Getting to know your neighbours can help you to become part of the community and make friends. Your neighbours are also a good source of help.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE OR FALSE?
The British constitution is contained in a single written document.
questions.explanation: The British constitution is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as 'unwritten'.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
The shamrock is the national flower of Scotland.
questions.explanation: The shamrock is the national flower of Northern Ireland, and the thistle is the national flower of Scotland.

questions.question: The Union Flag consists of three crosses. One is the cross of St George. Who do the other TWO crosses represent?
questions.explanation: The Union Flag consists of the crosses of Saints George, Andrew and Patrick.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
UK population growth has been faster in more recent years.
questions.explanation: UK population growth has been faster in more recent years. Migration into the UK and longer life expectancy have played a part in this.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
People can see the Crown Jewels at the Tower of London.
questions.explanation: True - people can see the Crown Jewels at The Tower of London.

questions.question:
Is the statement below TRUE or FALSE?
There is a dragon on the official flag of Wales.
questions.explanation: Wales has its own flag, which shows a dragon. The Welsh dragon does not appear on the Union Flag because, when the first Union Flag was created in 1606 from the flags of Scotland and England, the Principality of Wales was already united with England.
